01_data_basics/06_boxplots/01_read_boxplot_v3

A sample was taken from an unknown population. The values were organized into a boxplot.


For simplicity, assume no measurements lie on the hinges, median, or whisker tips (so we do not worry about inclusive vs.Â exclusive boundaries). This assumption is approximately true with a very large sample from a continuous distribution.


  1. What proportion of measurements are below 34.3? \[\text{prop}[\mathbf{x}< 34.3] = \text{?}\]
  2. What proportion of measurements are above 27.3? \[\text{prop}[\mathbf{x}> 27.3] = \text{?}\]
  3. What proportion of measurements are between 27.3 and 38.6? \[\text{prop}[27.3< \mathbf{x} < 38.6] = \text{?}\]
  4. What proportion of measurements are closer than 6.45 units from 27.85? \[\text{prop}[|\mathbf{x}-27.85|<6.45] = \text{?}\]
  5. Determine boundary \(b\) such that \(\text{prop}[\mathbf{x}<b]=0.5\).
  6. Determine boundary \(b\) such that \(\text{prop}[\mathbf{x}>b]=0.75\).
  7. What is the range?
  8. What is the interquartile range (IQR)?
  9. What is the median?
